title: Hugo Boss reaffirms FY on faster Q2 growth
text:
Q2 earnings grow 13% to EUR70.7m Gross margin down 20 bps Sales climb 16% 
Hugo Boss reiterated its full-year sales and earnings guidance 
Luxury fashion brand Hugo Boss has reaffirmed its full-year sales and profit guidance as it revealed faster growth in its second-quarter. 
In the three month period, earnings grew 13% to EUR70.7m (US$77.6m) from EUR62.8m a year earlier. 
Higher rebates and negative inventory valuation effects, however, had a negative impact on gross profit margin, pushing it down 20 basis points to 66.5%. 
Sales were up 16% to EUR647m from EUR559m a year earlier thanks to positive currency effects. Europe made a substantial contribution to this development, posting currency-adjusted sales growth of 7%. 
Sales in the UK rose at a double-digit rate, with the pace of growth also increasing in most 
other European countries. The US market showed, however, showed only moderate growth, edging up 1%. Bolstered by double-digit rises in Australia and Japan, sales in Asia exceeded the prior year's level by 5% after adjustment for currency effects. 
The company said it grew much faster in the second quarter than in the first three months of the year, with all regions reporting more favourable dynamics. As a result, management reconfirmed its sales and profit targets for the full year of currency-adjusted sales growth in the mid-single-digit rate, and EBITDA to increase by between 5% and 7% in reported terms. 
"Thanks to the very healthy development of the group's own retail business, growth accelerated in the second quarter," said CEO Claus-Dietrich Lahrs. "The excellent trend in our online business contributed to this. Because of our strength in the European market, we expect the favourable trend to continue in the second half, even though conditions in the USA and China remain difficult. Our investments in the brands, distribution and organisational efficiency will pay off this year and beyond."
